frontmatter.title: Préparation
frontmatter.summary:
This component consists of audit preparation activities that are needed to
ensure the components of the audit are able to be conducted effectively and
within the on-site time-frame.
frontmatter.short_summary:
Audit preparation activities which ensure all components of the
audit can be conducted safely, effectively, and within your time-frame.

frontmatter.title: Context Research
frontmatter.summary:
This component allows the auditor to identify the relevant regional and
technological context needed to provide a safe and informed SAFETAG audit.
This component consists of desk research that is collected and analyzed by the
auditor, as well as inputs from the Interview component.
frontmatter.short_summary: Identify the relevant regional and technological context needed to provide a safe and informed audit.

frontmatter.title: Evaluation des capacités
frontmatter.summary:
In this component the auditor engages with staff through both formal
interviews and informal conversations to identify the organization's strengths
and weakness (expertise, finance, willingness to learn, staff time, etc.) to
adopting new digital and physical security practices. The auditor uses this
information to modify the audit scope and recommendations accordingly.
frontmatter.short_summary: Engage with staff to identify the organization's strengths and weaknesses and use this information to modify audit scope and recommendations.

frontmatter.title: Reconnaissance
frontmatter.summary:
The remote assessment methodology focuses on direct observation of an
organization and their infrastructure, consisting of passive reconnaissance of
publicly available data sources ("Open Source Intelligence") This allows the
auditor to identify publicly available resources (such as websites, extranets,
email servers, but also social media information) connected to the
organization and remotely gather information about those resources.
frontmatter.short_summary: Use publicly available data sources to identify resources, assets, and information connected to the organization and which forms a potential attack surface.

frontmatter.title: Risk & Threat Analysis
frontmatter.summary:
This component allows an auditor to lead the host organization's staff in a
series of activities to identify and prioritize the processes that are
critical for the organization to carry out its work and to investigate 
and characterize the threats to those processes and key assets. These activities will
reveal the consequences if critical processes were interrupted or
exposed to a malicious actor, who will be understood through threat 
profiling activities.  This results in the staff creating a risk
matrix and threat profiles which are used as the foundation of the auditor's recommendations.
frontmatter.short_summary: Identify and map critical organizaional processes and profile the possible attackers in order to develop a risk matrix.

frontmatter.title: Organizational Policy Review
frontmatter.summary:
This methodology explores existing organizational practices, informal
agreements, and policies around managing information security and responding
to threats. It also seeks to reveal presumptions made within the organization
which are neither shared  (informal or no) nor codified in policies.
frontmatter.short_summary: Explore existing organizational practices, informal agreements, and policies around managing information security and responding to threats.

frontmatter.title: Staff Awareness and Individual Device Assessment
frontmatter.summary: This component allows the auditor to assess the awareness, attitudes, and capacity of staff members as well as review the status and security of the individual devices/endpoints (whether they are personally- or organizationally-owned) within the organization. This component consists of interviews, surveys, and inspection of devices.
frontmatter.short_summary: Assess the security of the individual devices in the organization through interviews, surveys, and inspection of devices.

frontmatter.title: Infrastructure and Cloud Service Assessment
frontmatter.summary: This component allows the auditor to discover and conduct initial assessessment of the assets used in the organization, for instance network and cloud infrastructure, servers, databases and other internal applications, cloud services and applications, mail/office suite providers, AI services, domain services or endpoint management, security products, communications tools, and social media platforms. This component can be considered as consisting of a discovery phase and an assessment phase. Discovery can take place through interviews, OSINT, network mapping and scanning, surveys, group discussions. Assessment takes place through inspection, configuration review, and checklists. In-depth automated or manual vulnerability scanning is handled separately in the [Vulnerability Scanning & Assessment](../vulnerability_scanning/) method.
frontmatter.short_summary: Discover and assess the security of infrastructure and cloud services used in the organization.

frontmatter.title: Data Assessment
frontmatter.summary:
This component allows the auditor to identify what sensitive data exists for
the organization, where it is stored, how it is transferred, and who accesses it.
frontmatter.short_summary: This component allows the auditor to identify what sensitive data exists for the organization, where it is stored, and how it is transferred.

frontmatter.title: Vulnerability Scanning and Analysis
frontmatter.summary:
This component has the auditor discover possible flaws in the organization's
devices, services, application designs, and networks by testing and comparing
them against a variety of online and offline resources (vulnerability
databases, vendor advisories, and auditor investigation) to identify known
vulnerabilities. Basic vulnerability analysis should be occurring along-side
the other activities so that evidence can be gathered from the network,
however, deeper research into specific discovered exploits can happen after
the on-site audit to fully take advantage of the short time the auditor has on
site.
frontmatter.short_summary: Discover possible flaws in the organization's devices, services, application designs, and networks by testing them to identify known vulnerabilities.

frontmatter.title: Physical and Operational Security
frontmatter.summary:
The organizational security methodology is focused on how to mitigate against
threats that occur because of the arrangement of digital assets in the
physical world -- how secure are the devices at an organization's office,
where and how staff travel with organizational devices, and whether staff work
outside of the office (e.g. in remote offices, at their homes, while
traveling, or at cafes).  Further, is organizational information accessed from
personal devices, and how are those devices secured?

frontmatter.title: Responding to Advanced Threats
frontmatter.summary:
This component allows the auditor to be able to identify, triage, and analyze
suspicious behavior on a device or in a network. Depending on the analysis,
the auditor may need to further investigate a malware infection, analyze a
binary and determine if it is malicious or not, and recommend urgent
mitigation steps.
frontmatter.short_summary: Identify, triage, and analyze suspicious behavior on a device or in a network for potential advanced threats and recommend urgent mitigation steps.

frontmatter.title: In-Audit Support & Incident Response
frontmatter.summary:
During the audit, the auditor provides assistance for any immediate action needed (spot training, tool fixes, consulting on upcoming projects or ongoing activities) -- this may also involve addressing vulnerabilities found that triggered an incident response.

Note that this in-audit support is not always appropriate and should match the needs and expectations of the organization. Some organizations prioritize an 'audit-only' approach in which no changes are made to systems, vulnerabilities, or staff capacity. In other cases, the organization will benefit from quick action to resolve issues. It is important to document any changes made, and carefully weigh the pros and cons of intervening, given the risks of unintended outcomes. Another risk is that the time spent providing this support will detract from your ability to complete a thorough assessment.

Ensure you document all work done, strive to engage and build capacity of team members so that they will be able to reproduce and maintain the work you have performed (rather than building dependency), and report on works completed in your final report/debrief. 

Continuous communication is also critical during assessments, and an in-audit debrief meeting may be offered multiple times, especially for longer engagements.

frontmatter.title: Reporting & Recommendation Development
frontmatter.summary: In this component the auditor synthesizes data collected to identify the organization's strengths and weakness (expertise, finance, willingness to learn, staff time, etc.) to adopting new digital and physical security practices and documents the possible actions the organization could take on to address the vulnerabilities found during the audit, the difficulty of taking on those actions, and the resources that the host may be able to leverage to address them. Resources can include, but are not limited to, local technical support and incident response groups/trade organizations, places to obtain discount software, trainers, and guides/resrouces they can use to support their up-skilling. Compile findings into an engagement report and provide a debrief with key points of contact, allowing a space for feedback and planning for follow-up and next steps.
frontmatter.short_summary: Synthesize data collected through the engagement to produce targeted recommendations then provide a report and debrief for the host organization.

frontmatter.title: Follow Up & Ongoing Support
frontmatter.summary: This component supports a continued relationship with the host organisation after the assessment report has been presented, allowing time for the organization to digest findings, come back for clarifications, and (if possible) receive additional support while they work to implement the auditor's recommendations or face new and emerging challenges. The auditor may also need to evaluate the success of the process.

résultat","404-message":"Vous venez d’atteindre une route qui n’existe pas… la tristesse.","about-title":"À propos de SAFETAG","about-text1":"Les audits SAFETAG s’adressent aux petites organisations de la société civile et aux médias indépendants qui ont des préoccupations en matière de sécurité numérique. En collaborant, les risques auxquels ils sont confrontés sont identifiés et des mesures pragmatiques et adaptées à leurs capacités sont établies pour y remédier.","about-text2":"Les audits de sécurité traditionnels partent du principe qu’une organisation dispose du temps, de l’argent et des capacités nécessaires pour viser une sécurité parfaite. Les groupes à risque à faible revenu ne disposent pas de ce luxe. SAFETAG combine les activités d’évaluation du monde de l’audit de sécurité avec les pratiques d’excellence pour travailler avec des organisations à risque à petite échelle.","about-text3":"Les auditeurs de SAFETAG mènent un processus de modélisation des risques qui aide le personnel et la direction à jeter un regard institutionnel sur leurs problèmes de sécurité numérique, à mettre en évidence les vulnérabilités qui ont un impact sur leurs processus et actifs critiques, et à fournir des rapports et un suivi clairs pour aider l’organisation à avancer stratégiquement et à identifier le soutien dont elle a besoin.","activities-title":"Activités","coc-title":"Code de conduite de la communauté SAFETAG","coc-missiontitle":"Déclaration de mission","coc-mission":"La mission de la communauté SAFETAG est d’améliorer la sécurité des organisations de la société civile dans le monde entier.","coc-whatwedo":"Ce que nous faisons : la communauté collabore activement au partage des connaissances, au renforcement des capacités et à la création de ressources, tout en promouvant la transparence et la responsabilité parmi ses membres, ainsi qu’avec d’autres communautés de pratique.","coc-communitystdtitle":"Normes de la communauté","coc-scop":"La communauté de pratique SAFETAG existe dans des groupes publics et privés, comprenant actuellement un canal Slack public, Mattermost du « Internet Freedom Festival » et le listserv orgsec.community.","coc-scopparameters-1":"Les membres de la communauté sont encouragés à être actifs, en contribuant ou en menant positivement des discussions sur les canaux de la communauté, en créant, en organisant, en évaluant le contenu ou en traitant les problèmes en attente.","coc-scopparameters-2":"Certains membres de la Communauté de pratique SAFETAG peuvent être préoccupés par la protection de leur vie privée et devraient participer à la communauté en utilisant un pseudonyme qui leur convient pour échanger en ligne dans les espaces publics et privés.","coc-scopparameters-3":"Pour participer à la communauté : obtenez un lien d’invitation pour participer au Slack SAFETAG en envoyant un courriel à info à safetag point org. Pour participer au Mattermost d’« Internet Freedom », consultez sur https://internetfreedomfestival.org/wiki/index.php/IFF_Mattermost.","coc-scopparameters-4":"La Communauté de pratique SAFETAG doit se conformer au Code de conduite SAFETAG ci-dessous","coc-coctitle":"Code de conduite SAFETAG","coc-expectationsopen":"Les membres de la communauté SAFETAG doivent :","coc-expectations-1":"Respecter les entités auditées et leurs contextes (dont le cadre législatif dans lequel elles fonctionnent) et protéger leur vie privée et leur sécurité ;","coc-expectations-2":"Protéger les renseignements qui permettent d’identifier et les résultats d’audit des entités auditées, à moins que vous ne disposiez du consentement total et éclairé de l’entité auditée. Dans ce cas même, faire preuve d’une extrême prudence ;","coc-expectations-3":"Ne jamais utiliser vos connaissances, vos compétences, ni votre accès pour nuire aux organisations ou aux communautés avec lesquelles vous travaillez, ni aux autres auditeurs et auditrices, par malveillance ou négligence ;","coc-expectations-4":"Minimiser tout conflit d’intérêts en faisant preuve de transparence dans vos contrats, dans vos rapports et dans vos recommandations ; par exemple, si votre contrat initial ne prévoit pas de mettre en œuvre des recommandations, proposez d’autres options que vous-même pour la mise en œuvre et fournissez des rapports qui permettront une mise en œuvre couronnée de succès dans tous les cas ;","coc-expectations-5":"Effectuer votre travail de manière responsable et correcte. Consulter les autres membres de la communauté ;","coc-expectations-6":"Respecter les autres membres de la communauté en tant que pairs et promouvoir un environnement sûr, inclusif et exempt de harcèlement.","coc-violationtitle":"Non-respect du Code de conduite","coc-violationconsequence":"Les infractions graves ou répétées au Code de conduite peuvent entraîner le retrait d'une ou de toutes les plateformes communautaires.","coc-violationreporting":"Pour signaler une infraction, adressez-vous en privé à un membre qui administre la plateforme concernée ou envoyer un courriel à info à safetag.org.","coc-contacttitle":"Contact","coc-questionsissuesemail":"Pour toute question relative au contenu de SAFETAG, signalez un problème à l’adresse suivante : https://github.com/SAFETAG/SAFETAG/issues. Vous pouvez envoyer un courriel à l’équipe de coordination de SAFETAG à l’adresse info à safetag.org.","contact-title":"Nous contacter","contact-network":"Nous disposons d’un réseau mondial de centaines d’auditrices et d’auditeurs formés au cadre SAFETAG, prêts à travailler de manière indépendante avec de petites ONG.","contact-learnmore":"Vous souhaitez en savoir plus ?
